• Group 1: A, B, E, I

Given the rule that people in different groups have bad relationships with one another (confirmed by relationships such as C and E being bad), O (in Group 2) and A (in Group 1) do not have a good relationship.

• Group 1: A has a good relationship with G, N, F, E, I, and B (from A–G, A–N, A–F, A–E, A–I, A–B). By transitivity, all of these people form a group.
• Group 2: J has a good relationship with H and M (from J–H and J–M). Hence, J, H, and M form a group.

Additional bad relationships (such as N–J and N–L) confirm these groups are completely separate. Since M is in Group 2 and I is in Group 1, they do not share a good relationship.

1. We know that J and I have a good relationship. (J, I in the same group)
2. We are also given that K and J have a bad relationship.
3. Now, using the transitivity rule “If A has a bad relationship with B, and A has a good relationship with C, then B and C must have a bad relationship,” we set A = J (since J's relationships are known):
  • J has a bad relationship with K.
  • J has a good relationship with I.
  Thus, by this rule, K and I must have a bad relationship.
4. Since a good relationship is required to be in the same group, and we have just deduced that K and I must have a bad relationship, they are not in the same group.

Thus, based on the given rules and facts, H and C cannot have a good relationship.

We first use the provided relationships to form groups, bearing in mind that good relationships are transitive and that if any member of one group has a bad relationship with any member of another, then every pairing between the two groups is bad.

Step 1. Identify preliminary groups based on good relationships:
• From N: N has good relationships with E, L, D, I, and B. So one group is {N, E, L, D, I, B}.
• From C: C has good relationships with J, A, G, and K. So another group is {C, J, A, G, K}.
• From M: M has good relationships with H and F. So a third group is {M, H, F}.

Step 2. Check cross-group relationships provided:
• We have “C and N have a bad relationship.” This establishes that the group containing C (the C-group) and the group containing N (the N-group) are completely separated.
• Similarly, “N and M have a bad relationship” and “C and M have a bad relationship” tell us that both the N-group and the C-group are each in a bad relationship with M’s group.

Step 3. Answer the question:
The question asks if H (in the M-group) and K (in the C-group) have a good relationship. Since C and M have a bad relationship, by the rule that groups are completely separate (everyone in one has bad relationships with everyone in the other), H and K must have a bad relationship.

Final Answer: No
